decision.summary: Local validation completed. Found 0 issues, 0 blockers.

nodes.name: False identification errors in biosignature detection of life
nodes.description: Risk that objects formed by random abiotic processes are mistaken for biological/technological products or that genuine biosignatures are overlooked, undermining life-detection efforts.

nodes.name: Absence of agnostic complexity metric distinguishing biological objects
nodes.description: Current analyses rely on domain-specific models, providing no universal way to separate biologically constructed objects from those formed by random physical processes.

nodes.name: High pathway assembly index necessitates extrinsic information
nodes.description: Theoretical claim that objects with large PA require external encoded information (e.g. genetic or technological) and thus signal biological or technological agency.
aliases: high PA implies biological or technological origin

nodes.name: Quantifying minimal assembly steps to set biological threshold
nodes.description: Design idea that measuring the shortest possible construction pathway for an object provides a pragmatic threshold above which biological processes are inferred.

nodes.name: Pathway Assembly index computation via assembly space modeling
nodes.description: Implementation mechanism in which objects are represented as vertices in an acyclic, edge-labelled quiver; PA equals the augmented cardinality of the minimal rooted subspace that contains the object.

nodes.name: Probabilistic modeling of PA demonstrates low random formation probability
nodes.description: Monte-carlo modelling of addition chains and biased decision trees shows objects with PA≈25 appear with ~10⁻⁷ probability in unbiased systems, establishing practical detection thresholds.

nodes.name: Pathway information metric measures uncertainty reduction over path sets
nodes.description: Design rationale introducing a Shannon-style information quantity I_PA=log(|N|/|N_PA|) to capture how much knowing an object's PA reduces the space of possible structures.

nodes.name: Calculation of pathway information using object counts to PA index ratio
nodes.description: Implementation mechanism: count all objects reachable within x steps (N) and the subset with exact PA=x (N_PA) to compute I_PA.

nodes.name: Information growth with PA observed in string example benchmarks
nodes.description: Empirical example (Figure 7) showing that for 12-character AB strings, moving from PA = 8 to PA = 9 sharply increases I_PA, validating usefulness of the metric.

nodes.name: Apply pathway assembly analysis to candidate objects for life detection missions
nodes.description: During analysis of planetary, atmospheric, or sample-return data, compute each object's PA and flag those exceeding the biologically-derived threshold as high-priority biosignatures/technosignatures.
aliases: deploy PA metric in biosignature searches

nodes.name: Establish system-specific pathway assembly threshold through bias modeling and empirical calibration
nodes.description: Model inherent process biases (parameter h) and combine with experimental data to set the PA value above which random formation is implausible for a given chemical or environmental system.
aliases: derive PA cutoff via bias assessment

nodes.name: Use pathway information rankings to prioritize high-PA objects in biosignature searches
nodes.description: Compute I_PA alongside PA to rank detected structures by the additional uncertainty reduction they provide, focusing follow-up resources on objects with maximal informational gain.

notes: Used local validation due to API failure
